reviewText: This DVD is a comprehensive documentary about yoga, its meaning, history, varieties and relevance to the modern times. It is beautifully presented and includes 45 scenes and interviews with many scholars, physicians, yoga teachers and experts, as they define yoga and give their views about how yoga can contribute to the understanding and solution of many of our current problems. We observe many contemporary yoga masters, such as Dharma Mittra, Priscilla Neel, Pandit Rajmani Tigunait, Patricia Walden, and Rodney Yee. Georg Feuerstein, the distinguished scholar who left us a few weeks ago, acts throughout the documentary as the perfect escort to the history and meaning of yoga. The narration is accompanied by a beautiful set of music pieces composed by Ashit Desai and Michael Karp.The documentary consists of two discs. The first disc is 142 minutes long and presents a comprehensive overview of the development of yoga since its ancient origins in India some 5,000 years ago to the modern times; it is very informative and consists of five chapters:  After a short introduction, the second chapter deals with the origins and evolution of yoga; it covers the long cycle from the "Vedic" (2,500 BC) and "Pre-classical" periods (1,000-500 BC - "the Wisdom of the Upanishads"), the "Epic Period," when the Bhagavad-Gita was composed (around the year 600 BC), and finishes with the "Classical Period" (500 BC-100 AD) which witnessed the consolidation of many of the schools of Hinduism, the Samkhya system of philosophy, the advent of Buddhism and Jainism, and the writing of the Yoga Sutras by Patanjali. The third chapter (46 minutes) offers a good summary of the various branches and types of yoga and is followed by a short but interesting chapter about how yoga passed from the East to the West, with special reference to the role played by Vivekananda at the World's Parliament of Religions in Chicago in 1893. The fifth chapter (46 Minutes) is devoted to the emergence of modern yoga, and includes short presentations about the legacies of such luminaries as Krishnamacharya, Indra Devi, B. K. S. Iyengar, Pattabhi Jois, and T. K. V. Desikachar. Through these summaries, we are told that the yoga tradition that we have today is the result of the interaction that took place during the last 200 years between Western scholars interested in Indian culture, British Army officers and a large number of Indian yoga practitioners, many of them exposed to Western values.The sixth chapter of the documentary is included in the second disc (56 minutes) and is entirely devoted to yoga as therapy. This chapter brings some of the key figures from the medical profession who have incorporated yoga as part of their medical practice; the list includes Drs Herbert Benson, Bernard Clark, Jagdish Hiremath, Timothy McCall, Dean Ornish, Mehmet Oz, and Martina Ziska, as well as therapists who use yoga for stress management, including Jon Kabath-Zin and Father Joe Pereira. The film includes many places in the United States (Hartford, CT, Boston, San Francisco, and New York), and Mumbai and Pune in India, where we can observe the variety of ways in which yoga is used as a healing technique.This documentary is strongly recommended to anyone interested in a video presentation of the history and significance of yoga. Dr Dean Ornish, Director of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute in San Francisco, and author of the best seller Dr. Dean Ornish's Program for Reversing Heart Disease (1990) says that "Yoga brings us back to our true nature, which is to be peaceful, until we disturb it."
summary: The best documentary on the history and relevance of yoga

reviewText: This excellent documentary, aimed especially at Western practitioners of hatha yoga, explores the origins and development of yoga, the branches of yoga, the transmission of yoga to the West, and the uses of yoga for health and healing. The film includes commentary by an impressive array of yoga teachers, scholars, MDs, and others (including B. K. S. Iyengar, Rodney Yee, Georg Feuerstein, and Jon Kabat-Zinn) and historical footage of some important twentieth-century teachers (including Krishnamacharya and Indra Devi).The film is divided into five parts on two discs. Disc One (142 min.) opens with a segment on the contemporary practice of yoga in the West (11 min.).Part 1, "ORIGINS OF YOGA" (23 min.), covers the Indus Valley civilization, the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Bhagavadgita, and the Yoga sutras. (I've used this part and the beginning of part 2 in teaching Hinduism to undergraduates and 9th graders.)Part 2, "BRANCHES OF YOGA" (46 min.), begins with good explanations of bhakti yoga, karma yoga, jnana yoga, and raja (ashtanga) yoga. Then there's a discussion of yogic views of the human body/mind that isn't clearly tied in with what precedes or follows it, followed by a brief and unilluminating discussion of tantra and a rather abstract discussion of kundalini yoga. Part 2 closes with a good, detailed exploration of hatha yoga.Part 3, "YOGA'S PASSAGE FROM EAST TO WEST" (16 min.), covers the Asiatic Society, the Transcendentalists, the 1893 World's Parliament of Religions in Chicago, and Swami Vivekananda.Part 4, "MODERN YOGA" (46 min.), profiles five teachers who were instrumental in reviving and shaping hatha yoga in the twentieth century and introducing it to the West: Krishnamacharya, Indra Devi, Iyengar, Pattabhi Jois, and Desikachar. (I think parts 3 and 4 will mainly be of interest to yoga devotees who've already heard of some of these teachers and to scholars of contemporary Hinduism or Asian religions in the West.)Part 5, "YOGA AS THERAPY" (56 min.), is basically a separate film. (It's the only part on the second disc, and it has its own opening credits.) It explores yoga's uses for physical and mental health and healing and the integration of yoga with Western medicine.
summary: Yoga's history, branches, and therapeutic uses

reviewText: As someone who's been interested in yoga for decades, I'm more into buying books about it, but once in a while I come across a DVD that sounds like I can't pass it up.  I've watched this DVD once and I'm looking forward to my second viewing because it's packed with information presented in a graphically pleasing way, interspersed with comments from various experts on the subject. I was especially pleased that one of the chief commentators is Georg Feuerstein, whose vast knowledge of yoga I've always admired and whose books I have in my library. This DVD covers the history and practice of yoga philosophy and asanas.  It's a bit pricey, but if you're a professional yoga teacher, a student of Eastern philosophies, or a practitioner of yoga who just wants to treat yourself to something special, buy this DVD.

reviewText: Very through, very well done, I'll view it repeatedly and review it more.  The guests featured are especially appreciated for their knowledge and willingness to share.  It's all good!

reviewText: To teach the world or even mention to us, a little more indepthly, the many Yogic traditions that we could choose from would be an insurmountable task. This video comes very close to that attempt. The auteurs of this production go on a journey to show where, how and why Yoga (asana, mudras, pranayamas, bandhas, etc) occured. Having watched this video only once, I was and still am overwhelmed by the information given here. A wonderful program for those who want to learn more about Yoga, what it means and how it is practice. Although westerners practice the asanas (postures) for physical reasons, we are not aware of the benefits Yoga gifts to us. After watching this video, which I may add is not to convert anyone from their belief systems, you will notice a change in your practice, a spritual change. It will bring you closer to that which you believe in.This look into a world which belongs to everyone is beautiful, purely educational and highly enjoyable. Enjoy...
Title: N/A
